title: Theresa May accuses anti-Brexit MPs of 'con trick on people' in hardline speech

Theresa May has accused anti-Brexit MPs of a 'con trick on the British people' in hardline speech backing Boris Johnson's deal.

The PM admitted she felt a sense of "deja vu" after returning to the Commons months after her own deal was voted down three times. Mr Johnson shot back cheerily: "I know how you feel!"

But despite claims Boris Johnson's offering is even worse, she forcefully backed the Prime Minister - saying MPs must back his deal to get Brexit done.

And she said MPs who backed triggering Article 50 , only to block the legislation now, would be "guilty of the most egregious con trick on the British people."

That led from an angry attack from expelled Tory Dominic Grieve. He said it was not a con trick when the deal is "so utterly different from what was offered" three years ago.

Boris Johnson barely betrayed a smile as Theresa May forcefully told MPs to back his deal.

The PM kept his arms tightly folded and looked towards the ceiling in her speech, tapping his arms on his own suit sleeve as she spoke.

But he did manage a smile when she cracked a joke late in her speech - turning round to look at her.

And he nodded when she said MPs must abide by the result of the 2016 referendum.

Rising to speak Mrs May was asked if she was going to rebel - at which she and the Tory benches laughed.

Mrs May, whose own deal was rejected by Parliament three times replied: “I intend to rebel against all of those who don’t want to deliver Brexit.”

(Image: UK PARLIAMENT/AFP via Getty Imag)

In an angry speech she asked MPs “Do we want to deliver Brexit, do we want to deliver on the referendum of 2016?”

She asked the House of Commons if the meant their votes to call the referendum and trigger article 50.

She said: “If this parliament did not mean it then it is guilty of the most egregious con trick on the British people.

“I’ve heard much from the Labour front bench on the importance of protecting jobs, industry and manufacturing.

“If they really meant that they would vote for this deal tonight.”

(Image: Amer Ghazzal/REX)

(Image: Tom Corban/REX)

It came as Parliament sat on a Saturday for the first time since 1982 to approve or reject Boris Johnson ’s Brexit deal.

At the same time, tens or hundreds of thousands of protesters were set to descend on Westminster demanding a second referendum – a “People’s Vote”.

But the vote risked becoming a total damp squib after MP Oliver Letwin tabled an amendment that will force a delay, win or lose - and put off the final decision until later.

That prompted No10 to threaten to pull or sit out the vote to avoid handing a symbolic victory to the expelled Tory and his Labour allies.

Today’s vote was already on a knife edge as victory hinged on just a few Labour MPs in Leave seats.

Last night Boris Johnson unveiled a last-minute offer on workers’ rights after his deal watered them down. But it was slammed by Labour’s leadership and the TUC as not worth the paper it’s written on.

Boris Johnson began speaking in the Commons at 9.30am with the final vote expected this afternoon.
description: The Prime Minister spoke out to support Boris Johnson's Brexit deal in the strongest possible terms
